I am baffled by this idea that "now is not the time to talk about gun control" stance when, to me, it could not be a more opportune time to talk about gun control.

The "now is not the time to talk about gun control" argument assumes that the wounds caused by the killing are too fresh, whether to the family or the community, to talk about a politically sensitive issue. What it ignores is that we are easily distracted, and that by the time we thought we would be ready to talk about gun control, we have forgotten all about the incident that was supposed to have provoked us in the first place.

Costas was smart enough to recognize this, and he was also smart enough to recognize that halftime of Sunday Night Football gave him an audience that couldn't be ignored.

After every shooting that makes national news, especially after every mass shooting, we are told that now isn't the time to talk about gun control. Just wait a while until the crime is no longer fresh in the public's mind, we are told. So what inevitably happens is that we end up not talking about gun control at all, and the next time a mass killing happens, we hear the same "not now, not now" all over again.

Bob Costas had the courage to break through the wall of "not now, not now" by saying "If not now, when then? Never?" For that show of courage, whether we agree with his point or not, he should be applauded.

Congratulations David that you have recognized the simple fact that in the space of one month it is becoming apparent that the GOP, being faced with the certainty that change in direction and leadership is required, has begun to embark on a new vision and direction. That the conservative values of the country will be maintained and strengthened is certain; that the emergence of a new, younger, modern and forward looking leadership is welcome.

In the past, having endured defeat as the voters made their choice, both parties have had to overcome major setbacks and look to the future and recognize where they can and will improve their message, their performance and their promise to the citizens and the country at large. There are talented,ethical and patriotic leaders in the Republican Party who will in the next year establish their credentials, make themselves known to the public and establish policies which will broaden the appeal of the party.

That Governor Romney has been defeated is history. That he learn from it and ride off into the sunset is a necessity. US politics has been unrelenting in seeking the next generation of leaders after being unsuccessful at the polls. The Republican Party has the opportunity to listen to the younger generation and benefit from their perspective. The party has a mission, should they care to recognize it, the reestablishment of the American Dream. The contest is now underway for the new blood to come to the fore. These are exciting times.

Morsi may be able to maintain power with the army's support for now but the Muslim Brotherhood participation in governing will be one of the elements responsible for their continuing decline in popularity. The Muslim secular elite has more to lose than the Christians as they are certainly not used to being treated as second class citizens by their religious brothers! Ironically, these secular elites are also supported by many from the poor and illiterate class (45% of Egypt), who rightfully accuse the Brotherhood of being as neglectful as Mubarak in improving their dire economic conditions. The youth of this class is also more interested in football than the Quran, a book they cannot read in the first place, and they are more prone to street violence. These problems will continue.

The sad part is the total lack of support the seculars are receiving from the United States. Our policy in the Middle East (Republicans and Democrats) has always favored stability in US foreign relations over liberty and equality for the people of the region. We believe that our interests always lie with the person most capable of controlling the population and we are gambling (for now) that it is Morsi and the Brotherhood. My advice to the seculars in general is to keep on fighting without expecting much help, aside of some rhetoric, from our administration.

But I wish to say to you, America was founded by men of religion and conviction who figured out separation of church and state is essential to peace. This is not a knock on Islam any more than America's founders wished to disrespect their religion.

Many in the west are alarmed that the Muslim Brotherhood appears to be consolidating secular power via "a whole way of life". I certainly agree that Egypt will and must make her own decisions, but do not agree that Egypt will soon become a super power--unless all citizens are comfortable with the government. I imagine it is difficult for Egyptians to see and hear many of their fellow citizens speaking western ideas, but there is no way around this in a 21st century world. And the best of western ideas is separation of church and state.The second best idea is guarantee of religious freedom.

The Middle East needs a regional leader--a super power. Most Americans don't really understand this. But I hope Egypt earns this role, weaves the best of western ideas with Egyptian culture, and shows the rest of the world what a truly cooperative 21st century Middle Eastern government can accomplish.
